ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: knowledge of basic acting techniques and principles
Better understanding of Stanislavsky acting theory.

I really grew as an actor and gained valuable skills in script analysis and otherwise preparing performances. I gained a lot of confidence in my acting abilities and was introduced to the craft of acting, as well as introductory level Stanislavski technique.

I gained a solid grounding in some of the core concepts of modern American naturalistic acting, with a good deal of understanding in both the theoretical basis of these, as well as how they can be applied practically in performance. We also gained exposure to a number of prominent authors on acting who laid out various approaches and techniques with which to approach both the performance of a character, as well as the creative process more broadly.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the material is very interesting (though I think less of an emphasis on Stanislavsky would be nice), the workload of the class was pretty irregular (the first couple weeks were very busy then towards the end it alternated by each day of class)

The organization in this class was loose. It was a covid semester and they tried to have half the class on zoom and the other in person which may have jostled the syllabus because it was adjusted weekly.

Generally, I like the outline of the course, starting with monologues, working through scenes, and finishing with the more flexible final.  I have two main pieces of feedback: First, I feel like it would have been helpful to have "final presentations," or at very least hard off-book deadlines for the monologues and scenes.  Having those deadlines would, I think, have helped me motivated myself to work on my own.  Second, while I appreciated the discussion in the first week about the limits of Stanislavsky, we then really only focused on his system (and derivatives of it) for the rest of the semester.  I feel like it would have been helpful to have even just a few weeks where we discussed techniques that are not founded in his work, because it's harder to grapple with the limitations of his style when we can't easily conceive of anything else.

The only real improvement I might make to this course is a bit more discussion of and practice with implementing some of the practices we read about in Stanislavski and Hagen's texts, since we did read about some of them without ever talking about them. Still, I really enjoyed the practice-based structure of this course, and I wouldn't change much about it.

Strengths: this courses attempts to meet in-person as much as possible!

Weaknesses: it could have been organized better to communicate with students how they were doing in this class other than the two meeting with an instructor. The only grades we received before the final grade (which I still have not seen as I have to submit this evaluation in order to see it) was the grade on one of the papers, which was only worth 5% of our grade. I think it would have really helped me feel more confident in the class if I knew more clearly where I stood and had more timely feedback on papers.

I really enjoyed this class throughout the semester. I was very grateful for the amount of time and effort with Professor Stokes and Professor Brooks put into ensuring that the course was informative and rewarding regardless of whether students were on Zoom, in the studio, outside, or split between different locations. The only way in which I think this course could have been improved is that I think it would have been helpful to get written feedback on the second paper we wrote for the class before we were asked to write the third, if this would be at all possible in future iterations of the class (however I understand that this was a very hectic semester for all professors).

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked the discussion posts

I really appreciated having this class be in-person as much as it was.  Obviously, there were still struggles with the technology, but I can't think of anything that could have been done better than it was.

I think that both professors succeeded remarkably on making a class which is usually highly contingent on in-person contact work very well while incorporating aspects of virtual learning, as well as social distancing and masking regulations. The online seminars earlier in the semester were very useful for grounding us in the core concepts of the course, and later hybrid classes allowed for effective application of these concepts within a continually COVID-safe setting.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Even if you don't consider yourself an actor, the class is very fun and teaches you skills that can be applied to playwriting and directing
Yes, especially in person.  I'm always a fan of acting seminars, and while this one wasn't necessarily special among them, I enjoyed it all the same.

Yes! Would definitely recommend to anyone with an interest in acting or performing, regardless of whether you're majoring in theater. This course will give you a great foundation from which to approach all future performing, and the connections you get to build with the instructors and your classmates are wonderful.

It depends. Its required for the TAPS major, but if youre just someone casually interested in theater, I think there are more interesting courses in the department to take that would feel a little less old dead white man-centric.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student. I felt that I received a great deal of individual feedback and attention throughout the vast majority of the course, and both professors were incredibly supportive and insightful on helping me improve my performance skills.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar
Hybrid course with virtual seminar/discussion part of the time and in-person meetings part of the time
Hybrid of in-person and virtual learning
